channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: That home-made sourdough? You might be better off with a slice of Mother's Pride!
item.description: Sourdough is said to be far superior nutritionally to 'junk' packaged bread, due to the fermentation process. But a series of small, yet robust studies in 2017 suggest that this isn't necessarily the case.

item.title: Why this crisis could be the making of the Snowflake Generation
item.description: As counter-intuitive as it sounds, experts say the coronavirus crisis - or rather, the experiences gained, and lessons learned during it - might in time give many of us a psychological boost.

item.title: Is a red rash another symptom? How skin changes could identify people who should be tested for virus
item.description: There are a growing number of reports of infected patients with rashes and chilblains - red patches on toes and fingers - and experts are keen to establish whether the virus is the cause.

item.title: Newsreader CHARLENE WHITE reveals how coronavirus has killed her great-aunt and two friends
item.description: CHARLENE WHITE: After weeks of trying its best to take her, Covid-19 had won. My Great Aunt Dell was gone. Just days earlier, she'd seemed better. But a second wave of the virus took hold.

item.title: China shuts gyms and swimming pools while country battles second wave of coronavirus
item.description: The country appeared to be getting a stranglehold on the killer bug, which first emerged in the city of Wuhan, but is now facing up to a second wave of infection.

item.title: Millions of key workers face a rush to secure coronavirus test as applications re-open
item.description: Many were trying to secure a test for the second time after the government's new website had to close hours after launching on Friday as 46,000 people tried to access it.

item.title: Intensive care units are running low on EIGHT key drugs as doctors are forced to use alternatives
item.description: Sedative drugs used to treat patients with the worst coronavirus symptoms in intensive care have been included on a list of drugs banned for exportation from the UK.

item.title: China global cover-up concerns after it filed patent for drug that helps some patients recover
item.description: China filed a patent for a drug seen as one of the best potential weapons against coronavirus the day after it confirmed human transmission of the disease.

item.title: UK coronavirus cases are still too high to ease lockdown, member of secretive SAGE committee warns
item.description: Tacking to a containment strategy based on rigorous testing and contact tracing is widely touted as the route to easing restrictions in the UK, but cases are still to high.

item.title: Mourners are filmed fleeing in terror as gunshots ring out at funeral of 'Mr Ibiza' in Manchester
item.description: Hundreds of people who broke social distancing rules to attend the service of criminal Clive Pinnock were forced to flee when a series of gunshots were fired within the crowd at Gorton cemetery, Manc.

item.title: DAN HODGES: The inconvenient truth for Boris's critics is that he did follow the science
item.description: DAN HODGES: When the coronavirus crisis began, Boris Johnson wanted to follow the science. But thanks to the paranoia of the Chinese government, there was little science to follow.

item.title: Russian doctor accuses Vladimir Putin of lying about coronavirus deaths
item.description: Analysts and President Vladimir Putin's political enemies wonder if his long and brutal reign might fall victim to the coronavirus crisis amid the perilous effects of the pandemic in Russia.

item.title: Son's heartbreak over 88-year-old father's funeral who died from coronavirus restrictions crossfire
item.description: My dad had a good and long life. Happily married to my mum for 65 years, Eddie was a father of five, grandfather of 12 and great-grandfather of 16. After his death at 88, it was time to say goodbye.

item.title: Garden centres risk having to dump 200million plants if they don't re-open soon, nurseries warn
item.description: Plant growers revealed they had begun dumping hundreds of millions of plants on compost heaps after missing out on sales on Mother's Day weekend and the Easter weekend.

item.title: Sky News presenter chokes back tears as she reads out obituaries for coronavirus victims live on TV
item.description: Anchor Kimberley Leonard became overwhelmed with emotion during a bulletin and her voice began to break as she shared stories of those who have fallen victim to the killer bug.

item.title: DEFENCE COMMITTEE CHAIR TOBIAS ELLWOOD: The global race for a vaccine will turn nasty
item.description: TOBIAS ELLWOOD The runners and riders include such familiar names as GlaxoSmithKline, Johnson & Johnson, Sanofi, Imperial College and Oxford University's Jenner Institute.

item.title: Trump claims he didn't ask Dr. Birx questions during disinfectant conference, but there is video
item.description: An embattled Trump took to his favorite social media platform to slam 'fake news' and to cancel the White House press briefings.

item.title: Police clash with anti-lockdown protesters in Germany as more than 100 are arrested
item.description: German police wearing riot gear and face masks clashed with dozens of protesters demonstrating in central Berlin against the coronavirus lockdown on public life, with more than 100 people arrested.

item.title: Gatwick boss says passengers should be given compulsory virus tests 48 hours before they fly
item.description: Stewart Wingate, the chief executive of Britain's second-busiest airport, also called for passengers to be required to carry 'health passports' and to wear face coverings on flights.

item.title: Vogue editor Anna 'Nuclear' Wintour has fallen out with her right-hand man Andre Leon Talley...
item.description: There was a time when Andre Leon Talley's friendship with Dame Anna Wintour was regarded as a match made in fashion heaven.

item.title: Gwent Police officer in serious confition after being repeatedly stabbed during coronavirus call-out
item.description: Gwent Police Sergeant Carl Banks was left in a serious condition after being stabbed multiple times in the belly during a coronavirus call out. Surgeons removed two parts of his bowel.

item.title: Hero just for one day: How David Bowie saved fellow rocker Peter Frampton from a burning plane
item.description: In his memoir rocker Peter Frampton, 69, reveals David Bowie - a 'lovely man' who he first met when they went to school together in Bromley, south east London - saved him twice.

item.title: DR ELLIE CANNON: Should my kids wear a mask... and should I if no one else does?
item.description: DR ELLIE CANNON: A makeshift face-covering stops you from passing on the virus if you are infected, even if you don't have any symptoms or haven't started showing them yet.

item.title: High Street stores to close changing rooms, toilets and limit customers when re-open after lockdown
item.description: Shoppers across Britain will have to follow strict guidelines when high street stores reopen - including being asked to shop alone or to buy new clothes without trying them on.

item.title: Government orders 50MILLION antibody testing kits that work in 20 minutes and could be ready by June
item.description: Ministers have ordered production of up to 50 million new immunity tests as part of what experts hope will be a 'game-changing' development in the battle against Covid-19.

item.title: DAVID MILIBAND: This is a battle for the future of democracy
item.description: DAVID MILIBAND Last year was the first in more than 100 years that the total income of countries governed by authoritarian systems outstripped that generated by democracies.

item.title: Anyone flying into the UK will have to self-isolate for 14 days under new Government plans
item.description: The move follows growing pressure for tighter border controls during the coronavirus crisis and would include UK citizens returning from abroad.

item.title: Boris Johnson says he is 'raring to go' and will start work on Monday
item.description: The Prime Minister told aides during a three-hour Covid-19 strategy session that doctors had given him permission to return.

item.title: Britain's first coronavirus 'super-spreader' helped scientists develop £10 immunity test
item.description: British businessman Steve Walsh was one of Britain's first coronavirus superspreaders and his movements were analysed by scientists to help develop an immunity test.

item.title: Border Force officials seize £1million of cocaine hidden in shipment of facemasks
item.description: Britain's Home Secretary last night condemned 'sophisticated' criminals seeking to 'exploit and capitalise' on the pandemic after £1 million of cocaine concealed in a shipment of face masks.

item.title: NAZIR AFZAL's memoirs show officials failing for fear of looking racist
item.description: Chief crown prosecutor Nazir Afzal courageously pursued justice for a girl named Safiya. One of her captors Ilyas Ashar, pictured, would climb into her bed in the cellar and sexually abuse her.

item.title: Top Tories join calls to ban Dominic Cummings from coronavirus scientific briefings
item.description: The former Brexit secretary David Davis said that Cummings's presence could alter the advice offered in meetings. It was last night revealed the PM's chief aide had attended Sage meetings.

item.title: Almost 200 staff who work for Prince Charles are furloughed
item.description: Almost 200 people who work for the Prince of Wales have been furloughed as a result of the coronavirus crisis - but it won't cost the taxpayer a penny.

item.title: Everton condemn Moise Kean after striker hosted house party during coronavirus lockdown
item.description: The 20-year-old reportedly sent footage of himself partying at his Cheshire apartment to a private Snapchat group. Everton have said they are 'appalled' by Kean's social media antics.

item.title: Countess of Wessex is secretly volunteering
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Sophie, wife of the Queen's son, Prince Edward, has been volunteering once a week in London with chefs organised by the millionaire financier Ian Wace,

item.title: Global coronavirus fatalities top 200,000 with 2.8million confirmed infections
item.description: The latest coronavirus death figures from the John Hopkins University show that the virus has now killed 200,000 people globally and infected 2.8million. The true figures are likely much higher.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn's brother Piers, 73, leads protest against coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Piers Corbyn spearheaded the rally in Glastonbury, Somerset, against the Government's lockdown, which he said was causing more people to die. He claimed that around 100 attended the protest.

item.title: PETER HITCHENS: Don't be fooled by the sunshine - there are only dark days ahead
item.description: PETER HITCHENS: I have come to hate this beautiful weather, the loveliest spring for 50 years.

item.title: Britain's tycoons are living lives of luxury in Monaco but you're paying furloughed staff's wages
item.description: Super-rich tycoons living in the tax haven of Monaco are using millions of pounds of British taxpayers' cash to pay the wages of the staff who have been furloughed in their UK companies.

item.title: SIR GRAHAM BRADY: Why can Tesco sell flowers but not the stalls in my local market?
item.description: SIR GRAHAM BRADY: Why are supermarkets allowed to sell flowers while flower stalls such as the one in Altrincham Market in my constituency cannot?

item.title: Britain breaches grim 20,000 death milestone: Another 813 deaths are announced in the UK
item.description: In the daily address to the nation this evening, the Home Secretary said the country was not ready to see an ease in lockdown restrictions which have entered a fifth weekend.

item.title: The sky really IS a deeper shade of blue
item.description: It might seem like a cruel trick of the mind for those trapped indoors during lockdown - but Britain's skies really have turned a deeper shade of blue.

item.title: Lawyers demand Epstein's estate hands over any Prince Andrew evidence
item.description: In court papers lodged last week, they have demanded that Epstein's estate hand over any photographs of the Duke, who was friends with the shamed financier for more than a decade.

item.title: Judges told to stop using 'beyond reasonable doubt' because jurors don't understand what it means
item.description: British judges have been told to stop using the phrase 'beyond reasonable doubt' because there are concerns that jurors don't understand what the phrase actually means.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing could be postponed until next year
item.description: Strictly Come Dancing fans could be bitterly disappointed this year as the coronavirus pandemic threatens to wreck the hit BBC show's filming schedules.

item.title: Government adviser says pubs should re-open as long as they don't get overcrowded
item.description: Pubs have been shut since the UK went into lockdown on March 23, but Professor Robert Dingwall (pictured) said it is time to relax the rules.

item.title: Lawyer of 'Coughing Major' says high-tech audio analysis can prove he is innocent
item.description: EXCLUSIVE The lawyer for the 'Coughing Major' hopes that new scientific analysis of audio tapes could lead to his conviction being overturned, The Mail on Sunday can reveal.

item.title: Sir Keir Starmer's new policy chief is pro-Brexit and a far cry from Jeremy Corbyn's Labour
item.description: As well as believing that leaving the EU is an 'opportunity' for Britain, Claire Ainsley is an ardent pro-family campaigner.

item.title: Is Van Dyck 'selfie' that Kate Middleton helped raise £10million to save a cheap dud?
item.description: In a side-room at the National Portrait Gallery in Trafalgar Square hangs a small oval portrait of a moustachioed man in a gilt baroque frame.

item.title: Shocking picture of bats for sale in Indonesia shows wet markets are still open
item.description: Since I have begun to write on the urgent need to close live animal markets, I have been surprised by the support I have received from across the UK.

item.title: Sweden's virus expert is so popular that people are getting his FACE as a tattoo
item.description: Anders Tegnell, 63, state epidemiologist with the Public Health Agency of Sweden and the architect of its Covid-19 response, is so popular that people in Stockholm are getting tattoos of him.

item.title: Victoria Beckham unrepentant for spending taxpayer cash on furloughed staff and thinks she's victim
item.description: Last Sunday was the third and final day of Victoria Beckham's extended 46th birthday celebrations. Already she had enjoyed a 'virtual' party hosted by a celebrity DJ friend and broadcast on Instagram.

item.title: PATRICK JEPHSON urges Harry and Meghan to give up their 'celebrity lives'
item.description: PATRICK JEPHSON Viewers of a solidly unflashy American TV business show might have thought they'd tuned in to the wrong channel last Friday.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle 'give interviews to two journalists writing flattering biography
item.description: British-Iranian biographer and journalist Omid Scobie (pictured) planted his flag firmly in Meghan's camp soon after she became linked to Harry.

item.title: Trump reined in? White House could curtail president's role in daily briefings
item.description: President Donald Trump may be forced to take a back seat at the daily coronavirus task force press briefings, as White House officials look to make up for Thursday's disinfectant blunder.

item.title: NHS leaders beg for boiler suits and painter's coveralls amid shortage of PPE
item.description: The shortage of gowns, masks and gloves in Devon's NHS clinical commissioning group has been so severe, that a local council have put out a tender for the 'immediate supply' of the items.

item.title: Laurence Fox, 41, finds love again with photographer, Sara McKinnon
item.description: British actor Laurence Fox's stormy divorce from actress Billie Piper and the rancorous custody battle over their two sons left the star needing therapy.

item.title: China sends medics to North Korea amid claims in Japanese media Kim Jong Un is in a vegetative state
item.description: The North Korean dictator, 36, who was last seen in public on April 11, has been reported to have died by a Hong Kong Satellite Television director.

item.title: Jennifer Aniston, 51, forgives her estranged father, 86, for walking out on her
item.description: She needed years of therapy to cope with the abandonment issues she suffered after her father walked out on her as a child.

item.title: Brits emerge from lockdown as new figures show rise in people outdoors
item.description: The British public are hitting the roads again this weekend as new figures show traffic congestion is steadily rising as people emerg from an enforced hibernation to breach strict lockdown rules.

item.title: The Metro, Panda and Astra are now 40-year-old classics
item.description: We've cast our minds back 40 years to identify 10 cars that now - technically - could qualify for free classic car taxation, from unlikely motors to iconic models that hit the market in 1980.

item.title: The Rolling Stones land their first ever Number One on iTunes with 'Living in a Ghost Town'
item.description: The single 'Living In A Ghost Town' - the British band's first for eight years - beat stars including Travis Scott, The Weeknd and Drake to reach the pinnacle.

item.title: Donald Trump unfollows Piers Morgan after GMB host blasted 'bats*** crazy' approach to coronavirus
item.description: Piers, 55, criticised the US President after he suggested tackling coronavirus with the use of 'powerful' UV light or even injecting patients with disinfectant.

item.title: Disabled orphans fall sick with coronavirus in Belarus after president dismissed disease fears
item.description: Ten staff members have also been infected at the Vesnova orphanage in the central Hlusk district, home to 147 young people who suffer from severe disabilities and weak immune systems.

item.title: Couple who drove 300 miles for a 'mini break' have their car seized for breaking lockdown rules
item.description: Enforcement action was taken after a police officer found the pair, who had travelled without insurance and a driving licence, flouting government guidance while on patrol in Falmouth.

item.title: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: Do statins raise the risk of Covid-19? Well, I've not stopped taking mine
item.description: DR MICHAEL MOSLEY: A claim online said having high cholesterol might help fight the coronavirus. But as far as I can see, there is no evidence that giving up statins will protect you against Covid-19.

item.title: Iran officials warn 'hasty re-openings' could trigger new wave of coronavirus
item.description: Iran has paid the deadliest price in the Middle East from the pandemic. Now another 76 fatalities have been declared amid the easing of lockdown measures - taking Iran's official death toll to 6,650.

item.title: ONE-FIFTH of all global ocean cruise ships were infected with coronavirus
item.description: Cases of the deadly virus can be directly linked to at least 54 cruise ships, according to a shocking new study by the Miami Herald.

item.title: Meghan and Harry biography bombshell for Royals
item.description: Palace insiders expect the biography - provisionally entitled Thoroughly Modern Royals: The Real World Of Harry And Meghan - to paint a flattering portrait of the couple.

item.title: Marilyn Monroe 'aborted a child shortly after trysts with JFK and RFK' weeks before she died
item.description: A new biography about Marilyn Monroe suggests she may have aborted a child from either John or Robert Kennedy, just weeks before she died of a drug overdose in her Los Angeles home in 1962.

item.title: Belgium unveils plans to reopen all shops and schools within three weeks
item.description: Leaders in Brussels and New Delhi are among a wave of nations cautiously hoping they have weathered the worst of the pandemic.

item.title: We MUST find out why so many black and Asian Britons are dying from coronavirus, doctors urge
item.description: Britain's most senior doctors have demanded immediate Government action to tackle soaring fatalities from Covid-19 in black and Asian communities, the Mail on Sunday can reveal.

item.title: Coronavirus patients who get put on a ventilator have just a 34% chance of survival, new study shows
item.description: The figures come from the Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre (ICNARC) and are based on a sample of 6,720 critically-ill coronavirus patients.

item.title: Priti Patel slams 'extraordinarily dangerous driving' on lockdown
item.description: The home secretary revealed that one Covidiot was clocked at 151mph on the M1 while another in London was racing at 134mph in a 40mph zone.

item.title: Government removes China from its official coronavirus death toll comparison list
item.description: Downing Street has removed China from a list it publishes alongside its daily coronavirus briefings that compares other country's coronavirus figures.

item.title: Fury at Dominic Cummings' wife using BBC Radio 4 slot to say how 'extremely kind' he is
item.description: Mary Wakefield, wife of Dominic Cummings said her husband raced home when she developed Covid-19. She was speaking during a broadcast on a BBC Radio 4 slot this morning.

item.title: Shops will have to enforce rules when lockdown is eased to support police, warns ex-chief constable
item.description: Sir Peter Fahy, former Chief Constable of Greater Manchester Police, told BBC Breakfast today that police do not want to get drawn into 'game' of counting the number of people in each household.

item.title: Budget airline Wizz Air becomes first to restore flights from London to European destinations
item.description: Flights will leave London Luton for Tenerife, Lisbon, Budapest and Tel Aviv from May 1. Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves, and planes will be disinfected.

item.title: Health Secretary Matt Hancock shares photo of himself taking part in 'painless' clinical trial
item.description: Matt Hancock has shared a photograph of himself taking part in a clinical blood plasma trial which could treat up to 5,000 patients a week if tests are successful.

item.title: Shipwreck emerges from beneath sands on South Wales beach after it was battered by storms
item.description: The unidentified shipwreck was spotted on Rhossili beach at the Gower, South Wales after it emerged from the sands following storms Dennis and Jorge in February.

item.title: Donald Trump goes on a Twitter tirade branding Democrats liars
item.description: Donald Trump lashed out at Democrats in a fiery tweet Saturday morning. He insisted that he never referred to the coronavirus a 'hoax' and called Democrats liars.

item.title: Kylie Jenner pays $36.5 MILLION for lavish 'resort compound' in Holmby Hills
item.description: Not just a home, the 19,250 square feet space is billed as a 'resort compound,' according to TMZ.

item.title: Homebase reopens and DIY-ers flock to B&Q
item.description: Britons have pushing the rules of lockdown today as they flock to parks, beaches and stores including Homebase and B&Q across the country.

item.title: Cadbury spends more than £1million on a new logo - but can you spot the difference?
item.description: The much-loved British chocolate maker has ditched some of the words weight and slightly edited their tilt to, as the designer says, 'put the humanity back' in the brand.

item.title: Mount Everest climbers can have luxury tents, gourmet meals and even 5G reception at the summit
item.description: Lukas Furtenbach, the founder of firm Furtenbach Adventures, which specialises in upmarket expeditions, said every climber gets a tent boasting a bed, electricity and even wifi.

item.title: Poachers kill at least six rhinos in Botswana as tourism dries up due to coronavirus
item.description: At least six rhinos have been killed in Botswana after the region's tourism was stopped because of coronavirus. South Africa, who have also restricted travel, have seen nine rhinos killed in this period.

item.title: Stalker terrifies ex-girlfriend by living in her garden shed for five days without knowing
item.description: Laura Vance, 37, from Darlington, County Durham, had moved house in a bid to escape Richard Bradford, convicted of harassing her, but the 42-year-old quickly tracked her down.

item.title: Pakistani doctors go on HUNGER STRIKE over lack of PPE
item.description: Health workers have complained for weeks that hospitals are suffering chronic shortages of safety gear, prompting the arrest of more than 50 doctors who called for more supplies in Quetta.
item.media:description: Health workers have complained for weeks that Pakistan's hospitals are suffering chronic shortages of safety gear

item.title: Headmaster sacked for sending 'flirty' texts to pupils is reported after setting up online academy
item.description: Toby Belfield, 47, was sacked earlier this year by Ruthin School in Denbighshire, North Wales, for sending the inappropriate text messages to female pupils.

item.title: Britain at its best: Exploring the Llyn Peninsula in North Wales
item.description: The Llyn Peninsula is a 30-mile spit of land known as the Land's End of North Wales. It has 'irresistible' walking routes and beaches that feel like you're on a Greek island.

item.title: Care homes bosses blame death toll on hospitals sending back patients
item.description: The plan, drafted on March 17, told NHS hospitals that 'timely discharge' was important - and told care homes to accept patients who had not even been tested for coronavirus.

item.title: Watchdog host Lynn Faulds Wood died from 'massive stroke' moments after clapping NHS workers
item.description: Lynn Faulds Wood, 72, who lived in St Margarets, south west London, passed away at midday on Friday with her husband John Stapleton and son, Nick, by her bedside.

item.title: Former BBC Radio 4 presenter Richard Sanders dies, aged 62, after catching coronavirus in hospital
item.description: Mr Sanders, who presented the programme Farming Today until 1998, died after contracting COVID-19 while in hospital, current presenter Charlotte Smith said on Saturday.

item.title: Eating in restaurants is SAFER than at home claims top French chef Alain Ducasse
item.description: Michelin-starred Alain Ducasse said visiting little supermarkets put people at risk of bumping into each other and touching the same products. He also said few customers there wear face masks.

item.title: Six-month-old baby given guard of honour as she is released from isolation after beating covid-19
item.description: Six-month-old Erin Bates is one of the youngest people to catch the infection and spent the last 14 days alone in isolation at Alder Hey Children's Hospital in Liverpool. She has made a full recovery.

item.title: Knee-high robots that deliver shopping see surge in popularity in Milton Keynes
item.description: The machines have been working flat out around the Buckinghamshire town. Operator Starship said it has doubled the fleet's size to 70 in response to an explosion in demand.

item.title: Sales of wine, beer and spirits up 31 per cent (and hair clippers have sold out too)
item.description: Wine (stock image) has been the most popular drink of lockdown, according to research, followed by lager, gin and whisky. Grocery sales also climbed to £10.8billion in March.

item.title: Russian helicopter spins out of control
item.description: A video shows how the tail of an Mi-26 touches the snow-covered ground in Novy Urengoy in Russia and breaks off, causing the chopper to turn on its side in a huge cloud of snow. Everyone on board lived.

item.title: New clip emerges of Joe Biden assault accuser Tara Reade's mother phoning into Larry King in 1993
item.description: A 1993 clip has emerged alleging to show former Joe Biden staffer Tara Reade's mother Jeanette Altimus calling into Larry King about the former Vice President's alleged sexual assault of her daughter.

item.title: BBC News apologises after mistaking Brighton Pavilion for a mosque during a report on Ramadan
item.description: The gaffe took place on BBC Wales during a live broadcast on Friday and was instantly spotted by eagle-eyed viewers.

item.title: Costa del Sol beaches will reopen tomorrow as Spain's daily coronavirus infection rate almost halves
item.description: Today, Spain announced that some beaches of the Costa del Sol will begin to open, six weeks after being closed due to the coronavirus crisis. They will be open to parents with children under 15.

item.title: Brazil becomes a coronavirus hotspot: New cases overwhelm hospitals, morgues and cemeteries
item.description: Pictured: A mass grave in Brazil full of suspected Covid-19 victims, where the country's President Jair Bolsonaro is still insisting that Covid-19 is a relatively minor disease.

item.title: US sees record number of new coronavirus cases in a day - but the mortality rate slows
item.description: The previous record daily rise in coronavirus cases was on April 10 when the number jumped by 35,579. The daily death toll peaked at 2,524 deaths on April 15.

item.title: Land Army volunteers are left without jobs as plan to get Brits picking crops falls flat
item.description: Fearing spuds, strawberries, parsnips, rhubarb and other crops will rot in the fields, planes were chartered to bring Romanian workers to the UK, but it's led to death threats for farmers.

item.title: Saving money in the lockdown? How to use the cash
item.description: While a lot of people will sadly have found themselves furloughed on reduced pay or even out of a job as a result of the coronavirus, some will actually have found themselves with more cash

item.title: Saving money in the lockdown? How to use the cash
item.description: While a lot of people will sadly have found themselves furloughed on reduced pay or even out of a job as a result of the coronavirus, some will actually have found themselves with more cash

item.title: New figures show number of people visiting UK's A&E wards down by half this month
item.description: Health officials are worried many people are not seeking treatment because they fear contracting Covid-19, thereby jeopardising their survival and potentially becoming collateral damage.

item.title: Terminally ill ex-CBBC star battling cystic fibrosis fears she won't live to see end of lockdown
item.description: Chelsie Whibley, 28, from Denmead, Hampshire, must undergo intensive intravenous treatment at home after her specialist Southampton Hospital unit was given over to coronavirus patients.

item.title: No evidence recovered covid patients can't be re-infected World Health Organisation says
item.description: United Nations agency warned against issuing 'immunity passports' to people who have been infected, saying practice may actually increase the risk of spread as they may ignore standard advice.

item.title: India's Muslims bear the brunt of crisis after being blamed by government
item.description: One in five of India's 24,500 cases have been identified at an Islamic compound in New Delhi. Experts have warned that discrimination against Muslims could worsen the outbreak.

item.title: Ford unveils a 170mph ELECTRIC Mustang Cobra Jet 1400 dragster
item.description: The one-off drag racer can complete a quarter-mile sprint in less than 8 seconds and even comes with its own wheelie-bar to stop it from flipping under acceleration and a built-in parachute to it slow down.

item.title: Toddler unexpectedly dies after falling asleep while watching a film
item.description: David George's father found him unconscious in his bedroom in Glasgow after David left play-time with his brother and sister to watch Transformers. The toddler died of SUDC after falling asleep.

item.title: How 90s label Ghost has been brought back to life
item.description: Last night British high street label Ghost was catapulted into the global spotlight after it was chosen by the Duchess of Cambridge for her televised clap for carers appearance.

item.title: Inside Camilla's Birkhall sitting room
item.description: The photograph captured Camilla relaxing in an armchair in a room at Birkhall, the couple's residence on Balmoral, Aberdeenshire, surrounded by photos and trinkets.

item.title: Tough new brainteaser challenges eagle-eyed users to spot the eight charms
item.description: An infuriating new brainteaser by UK online lotto betting company Lottoland challenges you to find the eight hidden good luck symbols from across the world hidden in this patch of clovers.

item.title: Hilarious pictures show a curious cat hanging out in the most random places
item.description: Oliver, a pet cat owned by American Sondra M, has been captured in the most unlikely locations in his house - making for some very funny photographs.

item.title: Two men charged over £3million cocaine smuggling plot
item.description: Lorry driver Gary Sloan, 50, from Magheralin in Northern Ireland, and Jason Bunce, 57, from Kingswood in Kent, are due to appear at Canterbury Magistrates' Court later today.

item.title: Man, 60, is jailed for four months after weaponising his cough
item.description: Gary Saunders, pictured, admitted 'weaponising' a cough during a row at his local corner shop in Southsea, Hampshire. Saunders was jailed for four months at Portsmouth Magistrates' Court

item.title: Paul Hollywood's epic culinary tour around Japan, from street stalls to Michelin-starred ramen shops
item.description: Food lovers should visit Japan when the world returns to normal, says Paul Hollywood. He recalls the best meal he's ever had from a stall in Osaka and that 'Michelin-starred Pot Noodle' in Tokyo.

item.title: A million self-employed people are unable to access coronavirus income support
item.description: Despite several schemes being introduced to help small businesses and the self-employed through the Covid-19 crisis, there are still hundreds of thousands of workers being overlooked for support.

item.title: Kate Garraway is having 'hardest time of her life' as her husband Derek Draper battles coronavirus
item.description: The Good Morning Britain presenter, 52, shared another heartbreaking update with fans on her Club Garraway Wellbeing website, as she thanked them for their messages of support.

item.title: PICTURED: Man who died ingesting fish tank cleaner thinking it was malaria drug championed by Trump
item.description: Gary Lenius and his wife Wanda, both in their 60s, took chloroquine phosphate. The couple, from Arizona, had confused the cleaner with hydroxychloroquine.

item.title: Hospital secretary sacked for repeatedly checking her own medical records wins £270,000 payout
item.description: Sarah Austin, 53, was fired by Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, where she'd worked for 25 years, after using her hospital computer to access her and her mother's files 140 times.

item.title: iPhone SE review: Apple's £419 handset lacks bells and whistles but feels like a familiar friend
item.description: The new iPhone SE has the body of an iPhone 8 with the 'brains' of an iPhone 11 thanks to Apple's latest A13 Bionic chip, which enables it to capture Portrait Mode photos.

item.title: Cops patrol the streets enforcing strict social-distancing rules on Anzac Day
item.description: Sydney's Coogee Beach was opened briefly for exercise on Saturday morning but authorities were forced to shut it after three hours because of large crowds eager to enjoy the sunshine.
item.media:credit: Nathan Richter for Daily Mail Australia

item.title: Armed police raid home of Jacob Rees-Mogg's staff looking for firearms
item.description: Armed officers used a battering ram to smash through the front door of the family home of Donna Coles, 49, and husband Andy, 57. They live less than a mile from Rees-Mogg's country estate.

item.title: Dozens of oil tankers float off coast of Southern California as global lockdown sees demand plummet
item.description: Video released by U.S. Coast Guard shows a flotilla of oil tankers anchored off the ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach. Demand for oil has dropped due to stay-at-home orders globally.

item.title: Kanye West officially becomes a billionaire according to Forbes report
item.description: Kanye West has officially joined the billionaires club.

item.title: Thought your kids were a handful? Spare a thought for this isolated shepherdess
item.description: For while the rest of the UK has been in coronavirus lockdown, life - and death - have continued on Gray's remote 150-acre farm, near Morpeth, Northumberland.

item.title: Top EU negotiator Michel Barnier rages at deadlock as UK trade talks resume
item.description: Britain locked horns with the EU over fishing rights yesterday after the first post-Brexit trade talks in more than a month.

item.title: Cunning fox is caught stealing a box of eggs left on a doorstep in Leeds
item.description: A cunning fox has been caught on camera stealing a box of eggs from a woman's doorstep. Helen Greenwood, from Leeds, set up CCTV after three boxes of eggs were stolen from outside her home.

item.title: 40 million year old frog remains discovered in Antarctica, suggesting it once had warmer climate
item.description: Researchers in Antartica have discovered the remains of a frog that dates back 40 million years, to a period when the frozen continent was covered in temperate rainforests.
item.media:credit: Jonas Hagström / The Swedish Museum of Natural History

item.title: Old age 'officially' starts at 61... and just thinking about it makes Brits stressed, survey finds
item.description: The survey of 2,000 Britons pinpointed the point at which we think we're 'past it' at 61. It also found that three-quarters of us worry about ageing, and half say it makes us feel stressed.

item.title: Elon Musk reveals SpaceX will launch its Starlink internet service in just 6 MONTHS
item.description: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk shared on Twitter that Starlink internet will roll out in private beta in three months, will public beta starting in just six months to certain parts of the world.

item.title: Tiger King's Joe Exotic 'killed more than 100 tigers'
item.description: Erik Cowie, the head zookeeper at the GW Exotic Animal Park in Oklahoma, exclusively claimed to DailyMailTV that Joe Exotic killed more than 100 tigers.

item.title: Where did Britain's cocaine king stash his cash?
item.description: In less troubled times, Wright's early release would have caused quite a stir, for he flooded Britain with drugs that caused untold misery and destroyed countless lives.

item.title: Hospitals treat one new stab victim every 90 minutes
item.description: Figures published by the NHS revealed treatment after blade attacks increased to a record high - typically one patient every 90 minutes. Dozens of those would have tragically lost their lives.

item.title: Colour paint technology cools buildings by reflecting the sun
item.description: New colour paint designed to cool buildings by reflecting the sun could become an eco-friendly alternative to air conditioners, US materials scientists report.

item.title: Smart contact lens developed that allows diabetics to monitor their glucose levels
item.description: The new invention is being developed by researchers from Pohang University of Science and Technology in South Korea as an alternative to blood tests.

item.title: China names first Mars exploration mission Tianwen-1 after an ancient poem
item.description: Tianwen-1 is a robotic exploration mission to the Red Planet and is due to launch in the summer of this year - around the same time as the NASA Perseverance rover.

item.title: The stunning winning images in the All About Photo Awards 2020 photography competition
item.description: The All About Photo Awards - The Mind's Eye has announced 40 winning images for 2020. Monica Denevan from the U.S was named Photographer of the Year for an image shot in Myanmar.
